Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Good luck, Mark. Even a very aggressive form of PC can be cured if they got it all. So the nurse was not within her rights to tell you that it WILL come back. That is something that nobody can know for sure. While it might be a distinct possibility, it is also quite possible that it is gone forever. Take care, Chuck Thank you Highlander for the notation that NO ONE knows if it will come back! My honey has already metastasized && we're praying after chemo that we will BEAT this thing!
Posts.Title: Update on my cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Good luck, Mark. Even a very aggressive form of PC can be cured if they got it all. So the nurse was not within her rights to tell you that it WILL come back. That is something that nobody can know for sure. Posts.Title: Update on my cancer

Posts.Content: Our Fav Oncologist through the summer went into private practice & left the clinic. She provided lots of information as we went, and a preview of what we 'might expect'. I'm not (really) surprised by the back issues. The 'new' oncologist didn't impress me, and his response was "the CT Scan doesn't reflect anything"; didn't do anything further. The southern oncologist we met with on January 8th ordered an x-ray, and the degenerative joints and vertebrae was detected there. She didn't communicate with the Doc from December; and very honestly he wasn't really familiar with our case, only provided the results of the CT Scan. Monday THIS oncologist also ordered out a pain patch for his ongoing pain, since the hydrocodone barely touched his pain levels. I totally understand not blindly offering advice; and YES bone mets were detected early on. We're hoping to "hold our own for as long as possible" with as little pain & family disruptions as possible. "life as usual as possible" is the motto.
Posts.Title: Follow up

Posts.Content: An update from last summer's stage4 diagnosis; following chemo last summer. We are currently wintering in the south; trying to learn local protocol with the local clinic which was very frustrating. My honey had meeting with Oncologist who "listened" to his complaint about back pain; and ordered an x-ray. Then it took 2 weeks to find someone to provide us with the results: degenerative joints & arthritis in the cervical & thoracic vertebrae; no fractures. I've had time to think about it, and now have a couple of questions: 1) is there anything we can do to strengthen his back? 2) are there any activities/exercises we should be doing? or activities we should avoid? These are the two questions I've "secure messaged" the clinic after the diagnosis relayed to us earlier today. Any ideas or thoughts would be helpful.
Posts.Title: Follow up

Posts.Content: WELCOME! At age 67, my honey's PSA was 73 for the first test in May; then 83 in June when visiting the urologist. When looking back at his records, 3 yrs ago was 6; 2 yrs ago was 7; they (missed) doing PSA last year. I UNDERSTAND your concern very well! I started reading EVERYTHING I could get my hands on, including the Dr Walsh book Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. Even IF he is found to NOT have PC, it is a very useful overview of various levels and treatments of PC. Hopefully the biopsy comes back sooner than later, and your/his results are negative!

Posts.Title: This is all new to us

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RonDeF I am a diabetic and currently take Metformin and I was taking it during my salvage radiation treatments and I was also on Lupron at the same time. I am not sure about my personal results yet. Due to the aggressiveness of my prostate cancer (G9)with Metastatic Disease, my medical team is throwing all options at me. Next Tuesday I will start Chemotherapy as a proactive approach due to Metastasis and because they found Lung Nodules in my CT scan. Unfortunately the Lung Nodules are too small to biopsy or to be picked up on a PET Scan. My honey is also with Metastatic to the bone. The chemo 'stopped' the cancer growth in the lymph nodes. The hormone treatment has reduced his PSA to .23. Also has lung nodules. We just celebrated our first anniversary of diagnosis; have our 47th wedding anniversary coming up: our daughter says she's starting to plan our 50th! KEEP POSITIVE! It's all about attitude.
Posts.Title: Metformin

Posts.Content: I haven't been tracking that particular product; though DO KNOW it's used to treat diabetes. I would personally look at the Mayo Website to check for side effects of the product. For some reason I was thinking there are (long term) side effects from Metformin. (I believe there's a class action suit on ONE of the diabetes treatments). GOOD LUCK to you!
Posts.Title: Metformin

Posts.Content: Personally I agree with the MRI. Will it make you feel better? yes. IF there is anything there, it will show up! Probably as good if not better than the biopsy. FYI: my husband's PSA was 6 3 yrs ago; 2 yrs ago was 7. no one seemed worried. Last year it somehow got missed. This year was 73; EVERYONE jumped on the bandwagon, doing MRI & CT scan. He has metastasized, & immediately got into treatment. IF IT MAKES YOU FEEL BETTER, JUST DO IT!
Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: Personally I agree with the MRI. Will it make you feel better? yes. IF there is anything there, it will show up! Probably as good if not better than the biopsy. FYI: my husband's PSA was 6 3 yrs ago; 2 yrs ago was 7. no one seemed worried. Last year it somehow got missed. This year was 73; EVERYONE jumped on the bandwagon, doing MRI & CT scan. He has metastasized, & immediately got into treatment. IF IT MAKES YOU FEEL BETTER, JUST DO IT!
Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: We discovered 10 months ago that my honey was stage 4 PC: with metastasized bone + lymph. We did 6 chemo treatments, with semi-annual hormone treatment + quarterly bone strengthening. Currently problem with degenerative vertebrae in the neck; and (supposedly) with arthritis with a LOT of pain. Oncologist is giving consideration to Radium 223. What I'm reading is that there are side effects (diarrhea primarily mentioned). The Mayo website also lists rapid breathing & weight gain (my honey's already pretty heavy) as well as other side effects. Has anyone had experience with this treatment?
Posts.Title: Radium 223?

Posts.Content: My husband's has metastasized; so we're doing the Lupron + chemo. Yes, we have hair loss, weight gain, hot flashes, NO motivation. He's already overweight, however things could be so much worse. We might have missed it TOTALLY! Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Update: T3a Hub started Hormone Therapy (Lupron) & will start radiation this week

Posts.Content: Congratulations on the first step: Finding this forum! One of the first things I did after finding out my husband had prostate cancer was purchase the Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. It was MOST helpful! My honey just finished his 4th chemo session, which followed a second CT Scan. Our lymph nodes are getting smaller; what a relief. Someone recently pointed out to me that there are others out there in "worse situations than you". At first I was offended. NOW I am rethinking, and realize they were correct. GOOD LUCK with your next step/steps! You have an awesome support group here~
Posts.Title: OK Gotta get a prostate biopsy, advice wanted

Posts.Title: OK Gotta get a prostate biopsy, advice wanted

Posts.Content: Update from my last post: Hubby was diagnosed as metastasized prostate cancer back in May/June. Just finished last chemo; continuing with Zometa semi-annually as well as Luprin. Remaining hair is getting longer, though not thicker yet (he won't let me trim it... "It's mine & it's not going away! LOL). He's gained some weight. Hopefully by the first of the year he will feel well enough to start doing some exercise and try to get it back off. He's almost 300# & really needs to lose some of it. Our spirits went UP yesterday when Oncologist said we "have years left". HOORAY! I just enjoyed my last day at work today, and plan to spend as much quality time as possible with my honey. If we're lucky, we'll celebrate 50 GREAT years together in 2019: my daughter is already planning a party. This is our third bout with cancer. I can't say "thank you" enough to my support group, which includes that same daughter.

Posts.Title: OK Gotta get a prostate biopsy, advice wanted

Posts.Content: I really don't have a link to that blog. I'm also new. The book was Dr Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. After finding it on someone's [I]thread, I bought the Kindle format immediately. The book provided me an overview of what might happen at points, plus overview of types of chemo that might be used. It provided all of the terminology in a great easy to understand format. After reading the book, AND before the scans, my comment to my husband was "it's probably nothing; the labs were done incorrectly". Little did I know the labs were correct. We're trying to keep a positive spin on everything && have awesome family support.
Posts.Title: Thank you for all of your notes!

Posts.Content: I just finished reading a book: Topic of Cancer: Riding the Waves of the Big C written by Meg Stafford. Meg had breast cancer. NOT the same; but similar. She did chemo prior to surgery. You laugh with her, cry with her. She notes having support group, and her feelings along the way, as well as those of her family; not 'science' based. I enjoyed reading the book; my husband has no interest. That's ok! He hasn't ready any of the other items either. Each person is DIFFERENT! and reacts differently.
Posts.Title: Thank you for all of your notes!

Posts.Content: My husband was diagnosed in May with Prostate Cancer: PSA was 73; next month we met with the Urologist and PSA was 83 and he initiated the 'hormone therapy'; July we met Oncologist and his PSA was already down to 53. We did a bone scan as well as (MRI?). We have been diagnosed as 'stage 4; already metastasized into the bone & lymph nodes. In May I found your blog; discovered the book written by the Dr from Johns Hopkins. The book provided me with information/knowledge to prep me for the upcoming appointments. As the Oncologist says, "Information is Knowledge". Your group has helped me tremendously! We just finished 'our' second chemo session. ONLY 4 more to go. Thank you for your continued support!
Posts.Title: Thank you for all of your notes!

Posts.Content: Our Docs jumped into action upon receipt of the PSA: immediate bone scan & (MRI?) were scheduled, moved from Urology who did hormone shot; to Oncology. Next met with Oncology to get the scan results && off and running with chemo. It all went VERY fast! Because we were already in lymph nodes & bone we are 'automatically' stage 4. Now fighting!!
Posts.Title: Thank you for all of your notes!
